results.title: For love or money: a history of women and work in Australia
results.creator_credit: Flashback Films, Megan McMurchy, Margot Nash, Margot Oliver and Jeni Thornley
results.brief_description: Tells the story of women’s working lives throughout Australia’s history. Juxtaposes clips from feature films, home movies, newsreels and documentaries with radio shows, diaries, popular songs, letters and interviews. Explores the challenges that face women in the nuclear age. Narrated by Noni Hazlehurst; edited by Margot Nash; music by Elizabeth Drake.

results.title: For Love Alone
results.creator_credit: Western Film Productions, Australian Film Commission, Margaret Fink and Stephen Wallace
results.brief_description: The time - the early 1930s. The woman - Teresa Hawkins, 20; her occupation University student. Her degree - love. She studies it with a passion. It is all consuming. She is obsessed. In the 1930s women were not supposed to believe in free love and independence. But that doesn’t stop Teresa. Helen Buday gives an outstanding performance as a woman years ahead of her time. Sam Neill, Hugo Weaving and Huw Williams play three of the men who become part of her passionate life. Based on the novel by Christina Stead.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Western Film Productions, Australian Film Commission, Margaret Fink and Stephen Wallace

results.title: For land's sake
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones, John Taylor, Don Worobey and Hugh Foulds
results.brief_description: Buying land to build a house on can be a problem. Urban sprawl, unscrupulous developers, zoning laws and other bureaucratic complexities can dim the enthusiasm of even the hardest candidates. Using animation and humour we are shown the difficulties encountered by a couple who want to build “a little house out in the country”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones, John Taylor, Don Worobey and Hugh Foulds

results.title: For gentlemen only
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Kroitor, Vladmir Valenta and Michael Scott
results.brief_description: The story of two retired old men whose comfortable world is threatened when their hotel, formerly for gentlemen only, decides to admit women. The film shows how they react to and cope with this change. (Award: Toronto)

results.title: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows (A)
results.creator_credit: Bower Bird Films, ABC-TV (Australia), Pat Fiske and Megan McMurchy
results.brief_description: Fred Hollows was a controversial, larger-than-life character who was abrasive, determined, flamboyant, unconventional and full of contradictions. Some loved him, some hated him. The style of this film, like the man, is direct, forthright, warts and all. Rather than conquer and convert, his philosophy was to train indigenous people to help themselves and this film documents his work in Eritrea, Nepal and here in Australia with the Aborigines. Included is film shot during recent expeditions, archival material and interviews and glimpses of him at home and on the road. “For all the world to see” is bold, wry, intimate and ultimately a very moving tribute to an extraordinary life.
results.title_for_label: For all the world to see: a portrait of Professor Fred Hollows (A)

results.title: For all the world's children
results.creator_credit: Warner-Pathe News, UNICEF, Alfred Butterfield and William K McClure
results.brief_description: Portrays the world-wide activities of the United Naitons International Children’s Emergency Fund (UNICEF). Shows all phases of UNICEF’s operations, from the shipment of supplies to child feeding in Europe and the Middle East. Includes sequences on malaria control and anti-tuberculosis vaccination in India. Narrated by Dwight Weist.
